conclusion: Shadows are created when an object blocks part of the light source, projecting onto a surface.
The light source is currently positioned above the objects, casting shadows A, B, C, and D on the ground.
The shadows are formed by the objects blocking the light and projecting it onto the ground.
If the light source moves forward, it will be closer to the objects and further from the ground.
This change in position will affect the angle at which the light is projected and the distance over which the shadow is cast.
As the light source moves forward, the angle of incidence of the light will change, affecting the size and shape of the shadows.
Generally, as the light source gets closer to the objects, the shadows will become larger and more elongated.
The location of the shadows will change, shifting closer to the objects as the light source moves forward.
After the light source moves forward, the shadows A, B, C, and D will be larger and more elongated, located closer to the objects.
The shadows A, B, C, and D will become larger and more elongated.
The shadows will be located closer to the objects.
